Lastly, for those of us who follow foreign attempts to influence our political process, the President’s repeated questioning of the election results provides a blueprint for state and non-state actors to follow as they attempt to interfere in our democratic process.

In Washington, how we spend money is a reflection of what we value.

If my colleagues believe that elections are important and should be as free and fair as our founders intended, they need to approve more funds for our states and our clerks.

While I’m encouraged to hear many of my Senate colleagues on both sides of the aisle dismiss the President’s suggestion, the Senate now has to put their money where their mouth is and include money for election administration in the next COVID bill.
Second, it builds on the doubt that the President has consistently sowed around mail-in voting and voting in general, in a way that could further deter citizens from exercising their right to vote.

And even though the President doesn’t have the authority to postpone the election, the self-serving nature of his comments & the way they upend the very tenets of what it means to be American, is so disheartening.

Our elections aren’t about you, Mr. President. They’re about us.

First, the punch-in-the-gut it provides to see that the Commander in Chief is seeking to undermine the very institutions that make us the United States, as laid out in the Constitution.

We didn't postpone elections during the Civil War.

It sent a shiver down my spine, as I hope it does all of my colleagues of both parties.
